thread.title: Top chefs to serve special lamb recipes at sheep industry gathering at Tow Law

author: David Whetstone
title: Top chefs to serve special lamb recipes at sheep industry gathering at Tow Law
text:
What's On Top chefs to serve special lamb recipes at sheep industry gathering at Tow Law As many as 8,000 people are expected at the NSA North Sheep event which will also have a Festival of Lamb Share Simon Hicks (left) and Stephanie Moon (right) Share Get what's on updates   Thank you for subscribing!   
The Smith family from Tow Law, County Durham , are preparing to welcome as many as 8,000 visitors to their home on Wednesday, June 7. 
To be fair, they do have the space to accommodate them and the visitors won’t, in any case, be expecting a cup of tea in the living room. 
The Smiths farm 1,200 acres at West Shields Farm which is the location for one of the key events in the calendar for the National Sheep Association, an industry get-together called NSA North Sheep. 
Held every two years, it is billed as an occasion for sheep farmers to get together and discuss the lie of the land and how things might change. The election and Brexit are sure to feature this time. 
As part of the festival, and to highlight changes in consumer habits to producers, there is to be a Festival of Lamb with noted chefs creating a series of dishes using only the best British lamb. 
There will be butchery demonstrations by Jimmy Bell, aka The Lamb Man, from East Wingates Farm, Morpeth. 
Simon Hicks, head chef at the Lord Crewe Arms, Blanchland, will give barbecue demonstrations and celebrity chef Stephanie Moon willmake lamb dishes to sample. Read More 
Simon was born and brought up in Australia but has an approach to cooking that has been developed over many years while travelling to Europe. 
He will be out to show that there is more to barbecue food than burgers and buns. 
His recipes will include grilled rolled lamb shoulder and involve other cuts of meat. “I wanted to highlight the diversity of dishes that can be created with different cuts of lamb that would perhaps not normally be the number one choice for people. 
“I want to showcase to the producers what the end consumer is after and, of course, how delicious it can taste.” 
Stephanie Moon will create dishes to demonstrate the diversity of lamb as an ingredient for different occasions. 
They wil linclude a lamb sharing platter, slow pulled lamb with sticky sauce and tagine-spiced lamb steaks. 
Heather Stoney-Grayshon, manager of the NSA Northern Region and event organiser, said: “We are delighted for everyone attending this year’s event to have this new initiative showing producers exactly what today’s consumers are looking for. 
“The emphasis is very much these days on the end product.” 
Find details of the NSA North Sheep event, which also has sheepdog handling demonstrations and 200 agricultural stands, at www.nationalsheep.org.uk/northsheep RECIPE by Simon Hicks, head chef, Lord Crewe Arms, Blanchland.
